channel.title: Bond on Reviews Per Minute
channel.description: Recent content in Bond on Reviews Per Minute

item.title: No Time to Die (2021) - 163 mins
item.description: It may be strange to say at the end of a series reviewing late-Bond through a political lens but NO TIME TO DIE works by focusing on the personal.

item.title: Spectre (2015) - 148 mins
item.description: “I’ve been here before,” starts Sam Smith’s theme for SPECTRE. And we have. SPECTRE recycles so many elements from previous Bonds in a rearrangement that is less than the sum of its parts: a seven-letter title and insight into Bond’s past like SKYFALL; a shadowy criminal organisation like QUANTUM; Bond and his love interest getting to know each other on a train like CASINO ROYALE; a high-speed boat chase down the Thames starting from the MI6 Building like WORLD.

item.title: Skyfall (2012) - 143 mins
item.description: It would be hyperbole to blame SKYFALL for the ills of the United Kingdom after the 2015 general election. And yet…

item.title: Quantum of Solace (2008) - 106 mins
item.description: A victim of sloppy pre-production and the AMPTP’s failure to negotiate, QUANTUM OF SOLACE was clearly not ready to be made.

item.title: Casino Royale (2006) - 144 mins
item.description: Released at a time when the franchise had been overtaken in spectacle by Bourne and Mission: Impossible, Martin Campbell’s second slightly-harder Bond reboot wisely eschews a central action sequence in favour of an intimate and wonderfully tense extended poker game.

item.title: The World Is Not Enough (1999) - 128 mins
item.description: A Bond film infused with the spirit of New Labour from the opening action scene focused on the triumphalist national symbolism of the Millennium Dome and the economic regeneration of the Isle of Dogs to the scenes where MI6 sets up temporary headquarters in Scotland acting as an allegory for devolution.

item.title: Tomorrow Never Dies (1997) - 119 mins
item.description: There’s something interesting about these Bond films from the End of History. Wai Lin (Michelle Yeoh) refers to Bond as a “decadent agent of a corrupt Western power” and it’s a joke but a joke that the film feels no need to seriously repudiate or counter.

item.title: GoldenEye (1995) - 130 mins
item.description: The old is dying and the new cannot be born. Behind the onanistically triumphalist surface symbolism of this first post-Cold War Bond film with its literal graveyards of Soviet symbols and its rampages through freshly-capitalist Russia and communist Cuba, there is a hint of rot at the heart of both Bond and by extension England.
